Award.AwardTitle: Advanced Research Workshop on Future Trends in Microelectronics: Journey Into the Unknown Future Trends in Microelectronics (FTM-2015)

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The aim of the triennial workshop on "Advanced Research Workshop on Future Trends in Microelectronics (FTM): Journey Into the Unknown" to be held June 21-26, 2015 in Mallorca, Spain, is to continue the tradition started in 1995 and now reaching the 8th iteration, to provide a forum for a free-spirited exchange of views among the leading professionals in Industry, Academia, and Government. Topics to be addressed include the evolution of microelectronics including not only computing and communications, but extending to sensors, displays, systems, bioelectronics, nanotechnology, and electronics-related material science for the coming decade or more, The speakers are asked to present their own uninhibited views, opinions and critiques of the present and future trends, rather than their own achievements. Debates and critical assessments are encouraged. The resulting free-spirited discussion, with varied and occasionally clashing viewpoints, will be available on the FTM workshop website as well as the conference volume (to be published by Wiley) providing a valuable educational tool for young researchers deciding on promising directions for microelectronics research in the next decade.

NSF-1522997: Outcomes

Advanced Research Workshop:

Future Trends in Microelectronics 2015: Journey into the Unknown

 

While the silicon technology roadmap, based on the downscaling of silicon transistors, is continuing for at least another decade, the field of microelectronics has become far broader than digital and analog electronic circuitry.  It now encompasses such wide-ranging areas as energy harvesting, biocompatible implantable electronics, nanotechnology, sensors and displays.  Continuing our tradition of triennial workshops that gather together leading researchers in academia, industry and government for a free-spirited exchange and debate of views, visions and ideas, we held an invitation-only week-long workshop for 60 participants on Mallorca, Spain (June 21-26, 2015).  The workshop was entitled Future Trends in Microelectronics 2015 (FTM-2015) and the details on the organization, participants and outcomes of the workshop are available at the workshop website: www.ece.stonybrook.edu/~serge/ARW-8/home.html

Intellectual merit: The intent of the FTM-2015 workshop was to arrive at a far-reaching overview of the evolution of microelectronics (broadly understood, including not only computing and communications, but extending to sensors, displays, systems, bioelectronics, nanotechnology, and electronics-related material science) for the coming decade or more, as perceived by leading practitioners in the field.  The identification of plausible scenarios for the next decade is particularly relevant today, when the universally accepted ITRS Roadmap predicts the scaling endpoint is but a decade away.  The FTM workshop included invited oral presentations detailing each speaker's vision of the future development in a given area, as well as panel sessions where debate and rebuttals will be encouraged.  Unusually, the oral presenters were be asked to focus on their assessements and critiques of important new ideas or approaches, and not on their own achievements.  The latest advances and results obtained by the participants in their own laboratories were presented in afternoon poster sessions.  The working days were concluded by evening panel sessions, forcefully chaired to bring out the the controversial aspects of any given futuristic technology in the hopeless task of forging a consensus about its prospects.

Broader impact: The FTM-2015 workshop was be the eighth in the series of triennial workshops that brought together an unusually broad range of leading experts, starting all the way back in 1995.  At the workshop, these scientific leaders learn of the cutting edge developments in other microelectronics-related areas.  They strike up collaborations and, perhaps more importantly, gain an appreciation of the opportunities in other fields.  Academic scientists get a clearer view of industrial needs and perspectives, which often differ from the objectives promulgated by funding agencies, whereas industry captains are exposed to longer-term perspectives than typical for industrial R&D laboratories. 

The combined expertise of the workshop participants was crystallized in the FTM-2015 conference volume, to be published soon (October, 2016) in hardcover by Wiley/IEEE Press and priced for wide dissemination as a forward guide to researchers and especially advanced undergraduates heading to graduate school, as well as beginning graduate students, about the exciting high-impact research areas of the next decade as envisioned by world-leading experts.  Details on the FTM-2015 conference volume are available at http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-1119069114.html on the publisher's website.
